commit.message:
Prevent deadlock due to system call error (#159)

The MQTT client runs in the main thread which consumes incoming
MQTT messages from a `Thread::Queue` called `@read_queue`.
This queue is fed by the `@read_thread`, a child thread which
reads from a socket in an infinite loop.

We noticed that our application stopped processing incoming
MQTT messages, but did not seem to exit or throw an exception either.
Upon inspecting the logs, we saw that the `@read_thread` had crashed
due to an unhandled `Errno::ECONNRESET` while reading from the socket.
This had the consuming thread then sleep forever while waiting for
new meassages on the `@read_queue`.

It turned out that the `MQTT::Client#receive_packet` method had
appropriate error handling in place

```ruby
def receive_packet
  # ...
rescue Exception
  # ...
end
```

but this did not rescue `Errno::ECONNRESET` even though `Exception`
is at the top of the hierarchy of
[Ruby's built-in exception classes][builtin-exceptions].

The root cause was that the library also defines a class `MQTT::Exception`
and in the context of `#receive_packet` the constant `Exception`
refers only to `MQTT::Exception` (which does not cover `Errno::ECONNRESET`)
where it actually should rescue any subclass of `::Exception`.

[builtin-exceptions]: https://docs.ruby-lang.org/en/3.2/Exception.html#class-Exception-label-Built-In+Exception+Classes

verification.payload:
tree f47bfbda5012e8f14d612131339618dd6ab4b375
parent 271ee631f128e66732ece935e752f13970d4267b
author Leo Arnold <leoarnold@users.noreply.github.com> 1712098436 +0200
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1712098436 +0100

Prevent deadlock due to system call error (#159)

The MQTT client runs in the main thread which consumes incoming
MQTT messages from a `Thread::Queue` called `@read_queue`.
This queue is fed by the `@read_thread`, a child thread which
reads from a socket in an infinite loop.

We noticed that our application stopped processing incoming
MQTT messages, but did not seem to exit or throw an exception either.
Upon inspecting the logs, we saw that the `@read_thread` had crashed
due to an unhandled `Errno::ECONNRESET` while reading from the socket.
This had the consuming thread then sleep forever while waiting for
new meassages on the `@read_queue`.

It turned out that the `MQTT::Client#receive_packet` method had
appropriate error handling in place

```ruby
def receive_packet
  # ...
rescue Exception
  # ...
end
```

but this did not rescue `Errno::ECONNRESET` even though `Exception`
is at the top of the hierarchy of
[Ruby's built-in exception classes][builtin-exceptions].

The root cause was that the library also defines a class `MQTT::Exception`
and in the context of `#receive_packet` the constant `Exception`
refers only to `MQTT::Exception` (which does not cover `Errno::ECONNRESET`)
where it actually should rescue any subclass of `::Exception`.

[builtin-exceptions]: https://docs.ruby-lang.org/en/3.2/Exception.html#class-Exception-label-Built-In+Exception+Classes

commit.message:
Remove support for ruby 1.8 and 1.9 (#156)

* `require 'rubygems'` has not been needed since Ruby 1.9
https://guides.rubygems.org/rubygems-basics/#requiring-code
* SimpleCov is supported for Ruby 1.9+
* Always run RuboCop

verification.payload:
tree 3e9b79fa78b767ce31904dbf030d5ef0464ecaad

committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1677802532 +0000

Remove support for ruby 1.8 and 1.9 (#156)

* `require 'rubygems'` has not been needed since Ruby 1.9
https://guides.rubygems.org/rubygems-basics/#requiring-code
* SimpleCov is supported for Ruby 1.9+
* Always run RuboCop

commit.message:
Port CI setup from Travis to GitHub Actions (#150)

* Port CI setup from Travis to GitHub Actions

The CI setup on Travis CI stopped working. This commit implements the
same setup on GitHub Actions (additionally adding Ruby 3.x to the test
matrix). The old Travis CI setup was removed.

* Fix Rubocop on Ruby > 3.0

Rubocop 0.48 does not support Ruby 3.1 and later, so on those versions
require rubocop ~> 1.45. This also introduces many new cops. For now,
disable those new coops to keep parity with the previous setup. Ideally,
they should be manually checked, to decide whether to enable the cop and
fix the violation, or keep the cop disabled.

verification.payload:
tree 8292f3a4051e10788709c50ced4635d6a621bca8
parent 7e9c0baffa84a7e8ce92dda6c8eaaf83a89cc9fa
author Luca Ongaro <mail@lucaongaro.eu> 1676506328 +0100
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1676506328 +0000

Port CI setup from Travis to GitHub Actions (#150)

* Port CI setup from Travis to GitHub Actions

The CI setup on Travis CI stopped working. This commit implements the
same setup on GitHub Actions (additionally adding Ruby 3.x to the test
matrix). The old Travis CI setup was removed.

* Fix Rubocop on Ruby > 3.0

Rubocop 0.48 does not support Ruby 3.1 and later, so on those versions
require rubocop ~> 1.45. This also introduces many new cops. For now,
disable those new coops to keep parity with the previous setup. Ideally,
they should be manually checked, to decide whether to enable the cop and
fix the violation, or keep the cop disabled.

commit.message:
Backport OpenSSL::SSL::SSLSocket#getbyte (#139)

This backports the getbyte method which was added in this PR:

  https://github.com/ruby/openssl/pull/438

We only add the method to SSLSocket if the method isn't already defined.
I was able to test this with the following program:

```ruby
require 'rubygems'
require 'mqtt'

client = MQTT::Client.connect(
  host: "test.mosquitto.org",
  port: 8883,
  ssl: true
)

client.get
```

Fixes #135

verification.payload:
tree 4d3ab28f8a23437d24ac5bf79e0461f811363162
parent 8968969c50b0f1add8803ac442bb77aacaeeb9d4
author Aaron Patterson <tenderlove@ruby-lang.org> 1655328935 -0700
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1655328935 +0100

commit.message:
fix: unescape is now in CGI (#136)

URI.unescape was deprecated for a long time.
in ruby 3.0 this has been completely removed.
use CGI.unescape instead.

verification.payload:
tree 544a28294ae9c3a24003bc7b15c0e003af25f582
parent 1f3bd42eddc69e49d13d18c65ec229c681db7726
author CuVoodoo <35878664+cuvoodoo@users.noreply.github.com> 1627429943 +0200
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1627429943 +0100

fix: unescape is now in CGI (#136)

URI.unescape was deprecated for a long time.
in ruby 3.0 this has been completely removed.
use CGI.unescape instead.

commit.message: Switched from travis-ci.org to travis-ci.com
Added testing of ruby 2.7.4 and 3.0.2

Use monotonic clock instead of realtime for keep_alive (#132)

Since realtime is influenced by changing system time such as NTP, it's
not suitable for measuring elapsed time of ping.

Signed-off-by: Takuro Ashie <ashie@clear-code.com>

verification.payload:
tree 60d1f8545b0dd9670245a56f98be74ba289d2e4b
parent 49a73b8035922d619016fa5e933b9ca8c3d110cd
author Takuro Ashie <ashie@clear-code.com> 1615247196 +0900
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1615247196 +0000

Use monotonic clock instead of realtime for keep_alive (#132)

Since realtime is influenced by changing system time such as NTP, it's
not suitable for measuring elapsed time of ping.

Signed-off-by: Takuro Ashie <ashie@clear-code.com>

commit.message: Filter out spec files from the coverage report

Use a queue to wait for Puback packets rather than polling (#120)

This commit changes the `publish` method to use a queue to wait for
Puback packets rather than polling a hash.  Every time the read loop
gets data or a timeout from `IO.select`, it will send a message to
everyone waiting for a `Puback` packet.  If the we're within the
deadline, then the loop executes again, if we got a packet, we'll return
the packet, and if we're outside the deadline, a `-1` is returned.

This upside is that this patch speeds up the publish method by over
100x.  Here is the benchmark:

```ruby
require "securerandom"
require "mqtt"
require "benchmark/ips"
require "stackprof"

client = MQTT::Client.new(username: 'testuser', password: 'testpasswd', client_id: "client_#{SecureRandom.hex(10)}", host: '127.0.0.1')
client.connect

Benchmark.ips do |x|
  x.report("send message") {
    i = rand(1..10)
    topic = "to/timebox#{i}/cameras"
    msg = "message #{Time.now} for timebox#{i}"
    client.publish(topic, msg, true, 1)
  }
end
```

Before this patch:

```
$ ruby -I lib thing.rb
Warming up --------------------------------------
        send message     8.000  i/100ms
Calculating -------------------------------------
        send message     85.042  (± 4.7%) i/s -    432.000  in   5.089261s
```

After this patch:

```
$ ruby -I lib thing.rb
Warming up --------------------------------------
        send message   915.000  i/100ms
Calculating -------------------------------------
        send message      9.453k (± 4.5%) i/s -     47.580k in   5.043716s
```

The downside is that the timeout isn't exact.  Since `IO.select` times
out every `0.5` seconds (according to the `SELECT_TIMEOUT` constant),
the deadline in the `publish` method could be missed by that amount of
time.

Refs #115

verification.payload:
tree d356b975db9cb8d5a857a3b1ffd41fd315f15e3f
parent 1d15a4c89c20cc26a3739d8a32280af544559add
author Aaron Patterson <tenderlove@github.com> 1583743795 -0700
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1583743795 +0000

Use a queue to wait for Puback packets rather than polling (#120)

This commit changes the `publish` method to use a queue to wait for
Puback packets rather than polling a hash.  Every time the read loop
gets data or a timeout from `IO.select`, it will send a message to
everyone waiting for a `Puback` packet.  If the we're within the
deadline, then the loop executes again, if we got a packet, we'll return
the packet, and if we're outside the deadline, a `-1` is returned.

This upside is that this patch speeds up the publish method by over
100x.  Here is the benchmark:

```ruby
require "securerandom"
require "mqtt"
require "benchmark/ips"
require "stackprof"

client = MQTT::Client.new(username: 'testuser', password: 'testpasswd', client_id: "client_#{SecureRandom.hex(10)}", host: '127.0.0.1')
client.connect

Benchmark.ips do |x|
  x.report("send message") {
    i = rand(1..10)
    topic = "to/timebox#{i}/cameras"
    msg = "message #{Time.now} for timebox#{i}"
    client.publish(topic, msg, true, 1)
  }
end
```

Before this patch:

```
$ ruby -I lib thing.rb
Warming up --------------------------------------
        send message     8.000  i/100ms
Calculating -------------------------------------
        send message     85.042  (± 4.7%) i/s -    432.000  in   5.089261s
```

After this patch:

```
$ ruby -I lib thing.rb
Warming up --------------------------------------
        send message   915.000  i/100ms
Calculating -------------------------------------
        send message      9.453k (± 4.5%) i/s -     47.580k in   5.043716s
```

The downside is that the timeout isn't exact.  Since `IO.select` times
out every `0.5` seconds (according to the `SELECT_TIMEOUT` constant),
the deadline in the `publish` method could be missed by that amount of
time.

Refs #115
